contents.context:
The Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry is set to become the first business group to receive the Van Fleet Award for promoting ties between South Korea and the U.S.
The chamber said Monday that it's being awarded this year's prize for its efforts to boost ties between business circles in the two countries.
The Korea Society has been giving out the award, named after Korean War General James A. Van Fleet, for over two decades, to honor Koreans or Americans who have promoted bilateral ties.
Previous awardees include U.S. Presidents Jimmy Carter and George W. Bush, late South Korean President Kim Dae-jung and Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-hee.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
KCCI awarded 2020 Van Fleet Award for promoting S. Korea-U.S. ties
Updated: 2020-05-18 17:06:01 KST

contents.context:
The South Korean government is moving to stabilize the price of fishery products during the off season by releasing supplies from its reserves.
The Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries says it will supply a total of around 6,70 tons of six products, including pollack, mackerel and squid, from today through June 10th.
Their prices will be 10 to 30 percent lower than usual.
They will first reach consumers through traditional markets, large-scale distributors and home shopping companies, and the remaining amount will be distributed through wholesale markets or the electornic bidding system.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to release some 6,070 tons of fish reserves to stablize prices
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:29:54 KST

contents.context:
South Korea is holding a three-week virtual job fair starting today to connect jobseekers and employers in these difficult times.
Thirty-four small and medium sized enterprises are taking part, and are expecting to hire some 300 people.
The entire recruitment process, from applications to final interviews, is being done online, with no in-person contact.
It's being held by the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy together with Federation of Middle Market Enterprises of Korea and Industrial Bank of Korea.
More information can be found on the job fair's website.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean SMEs to hire around 300 employees in virtual job fair
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:28:50 KST

contents.context:
Time now for an in-depth look at the market news on this Monday.
And for that, I'm joined on the line by Dr. Yang Jun-sok, professor of economics at the Catholic University of Korea.
Professor Yang, thank you for making time today.

Thank you.

Stocks on Wall Street ended higher on Friday on expectations that consumption will improve down the road. Korean stocks higher today too. What's the story in the stock markets?

It seems the U.S. and China are heading into another trade war. The first one did a lot of damage to Korea's exports. Now, with the Trump administration look to cut off Huawei from its chip suppliers, what kind of effect is that going to have on the Korean economy?

In the next few days, South Korean high school seniors will be going back to class. We'll also have economic statistics coming out on Korean households. Tell us a bit about what's coming up this week.

Alright, Professor Yang.
We'll be watching for those numbers.
Thank you as always for sharing your insights.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
In-depth: Global market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:27:38 KST

contents.context:
With the surge in demand for Korean-made protective gear, South Korea exported more protective suits last month than in the past two decades combined.
Specifically, these are protective suits made of non-woven fabrics of the type used by medical workers.
According the Korea Customs Service, South Korea exported over 19 million U.S. dollars worth of them in April.
This is 327 times the amount exported in April last year, and is more than the total amount exported between 2000 and 2019.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea exported over US$ 19 mil. of protective suits in April; more than last 20 years combined
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:26:53 KST

contents.context:
Samsung Electronics Vice Chairman Lee Jae-yong, the tech giant's de facto leader, resumed his overseas business trips on Monday with a visit to a semiconductor plant in China.
This is his first business trip abroad in four months.
Having tested negative for the coronavirus, Lee left for China on Sunday under an agreement between Seoul and Beijing to simplify entry procedures for business travel starting in May.
The plant he's visiting is in the city of Xian.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Samsung Electronics vice chairman Lee Jae-yong resumes overseas business trips amid COVID-19 outbreak
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:26:53 KST

contents.context:
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says he expects a economy recovery in the U.S. to stretch deep into 2021.
During an interview with CBS, he said the economy could steadily recover through the second half of the year but a complete rebound will depend on a vaccine for COVID-19.
He added the recovery would also depend on how Americans feel about their safety.
Amid the sluggish economyHouse Democrats passed a three trillion dollar bill to address the economic caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
However, the bill has been slammed by Republican leaders as hyper-partisan and President Trump has vowed to veto it if it ever reached his desk.
The enormous plan would cost more than the prior four coronavirus bills combined.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
COVID-19 fallout could last until 2021 in U.S., hard to recover without vaccine: Fed chief
Updated: 2020-05-18 09:26:09 KST

contents.context:
The Trump administration has taken an aggressive move in hitting diverse sectors of the Chinese economy.
The U.S. has imposed a new rule on China to block shipments of semiconductors to Huawei Technologies from global chipmakers.
The new rule announced by the U.S. Commerce Department on Friday, gives the U.S. increased authority in licensing sales of semiconductors built with its software and technology to Huawei.
In response, China's national newspaper Global Times said Beijing was ready to put U.S. companies on an "unreliable entity list".
That means U.S. companies such as Apple, Cisco Systems and Qualcomm, in mainland China, will be subject to investigations and restrictions.
U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the rule is aimed at preventing Huawei from undermining Washington's export controls.
The U.S. had added the company to the Commerce Department's "entity list" last year claiming that Huawei was spying on its customers.
But experts warn the new rule could also hurt U.S. manufacturers of chipmaking equipment that rely on their sales to Huawei.
The Trump administration has also extended the prohibition on Chinese telecommunications equipment sales in the U.S. for another year.
In the capital market, the U.S. is planning to ban the board of the federal retirement savings plan from investing in Chinese stocks.
Hong Yoo, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. hits diverse sectors of Chinese economy amid escalating COVID-19 pandemic and trade tensions
Updated: 2020-05-17 08:58:15 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. economy has also been hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Both consumption and production showed the worst numbers in history for April.
The U.S. Commerce Department announced on Friday that retail sales last month had dropped 16.4 percent on-month.
This is the biggest on-month drop recorded since 1992 when the data started being collected, meaning that consumption by Americans has practically stopped.
Industrial production also saw the worst ever drop of 11.2 percent on-month in April.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. sees worst-ever drop in consumption and production due to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-16 13:02:24 KST

contents.context:
A new report says COVID-19 is likely to cost the global economy up to 8.8 trillion U.S. dollars.
According to the Asian Development Bank, the range will be from 5.8 trillion to 8.8 trillion, which is equivalent to six to almost 10 percent of the global GDP.
That's a sharp increase from last month's report, which projected a cost of 2 trillion to 4.1 trillion dollars.
The report says China alone could lose as much as 1.6 trillion.
The ADB, however, said governments around the world can take measures to reduce these losses to a little over 5 trillion dollars.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Global economy could suffer as much as US$ 8.8 tril. in losses due to COVID-19 impact: ADB
Updated: 2020-05-16 10:11:29 KST

contents.context:
Local airlines industry is reporting a massive loss for the first quarter with international travel at a standstill.
Korean Air, saw an operating loss of almost 46 million U.S. dollars.
Its sales came to some 1.9-1 billion dollars, down almost 23 percent on-year.
The nation's second-biggest carrier, Asiana Airlines saw its operating loss widen to some 169 million dollars, sales down over 21 percent.
T'way Air recorded around 18 million dollars.
Jin Air saw: 25 million..
The full impact of the pandemic only began in March, so analysts expect gloomier figures in Q2.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
South Korean airlines suffer operating losses in Q1 2020 due to COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-16 10:09:32 KST

contents.context:
On the first day of shopping with their government relief funds, many people hit their local convenience stores to pick up daily necessities.

"I'm doing my shopping at the convenience store because it's easy to get to and convenient. I'm going to buy feminine products and snacks, which I need now and will always need in the future."

Topping people's shopping lists were rice, sanitary pads, shampoos and diapers.
In fact, sales of rice at convenience stores jumped over 48 percent on Wednesday from the previous day.

"Customers are buying instant rice in packs and looking to buy more expensive products like bluetooth earphones. I think people are spending the money freely because it's not going to sit in their bank accounts forever."

People also went on shopping sprees at convenience stores for items that are normally more expensive there.
Sales of razors for shaving rose well over 70 percent.
And normally slow sellers like wine and ginseng sticks also jumped by double digits.

"The relief money is available for everyone in the country. So people are buying not only necessities but also things that they have been eyeing for a while."

Restaurants and food franchises, on the other hand, have seen no significant rise in sales, apparently because the aid distribution has only just begun.
The recent cluster infection linked to nightclubs has also stopped people from going to and eating at crowded places.

"From Monday to Thursday this week, almost 8 million households have applied for the funds. They'll have the end of August to spend it, so local consumption will see an increase, brightening up local markets over the next few months.
Kim Dami, Arirang News."
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Koreans spending gov't relief funds on necessities and luxuries
Updated: 2020-05-15 17:07:37 KST
